questions.q1: (1) In your view, what would be the connections among the concepts of home, identity, citizenship, and social responsibility?

questions.q2: (2) In school (or when you were still in school), how does (or did) your learning and/or teaching experience connect with the concepts of home, identity, citizenship, and social responsibility?

questions.q3: (3) How do these taught content, definitions, and school experience align (or misalign) with your lived experience outside of school?

questions.q4: (4) Specifically, have social-political events since the Hong Kong 2019 protests changed your perceptions on the concepts of home, identity, citizenship, and social responsibility? If so, how? If not, why?

questions.q5: (5) (continued) Have you got more conscious and motivated to act upon these concepts? How so?

questions.q6: (6) In relation to the concepts of home, identity, citizenship, and social responsibility, what are the current and envisioned roles that education (should) play under an unstable sociopolitical environment and modern globalization?

questions.q7: (7) How do you envision Hong Kong and its education in 2050?

answers.a1:
To me, ‘home’ is a place where I feel comfortable to be in so it’s less about a particular place. Thus, I would base off of the idea of ‘family’ instead of ‘home’ here and say that ‘value’ connects these concepts together. ‘Family’ would be an environment to instill morally sound values. 
 People who identify themselves with a particular ‘identity’ would be a group of people who share the same or similar values. Such identification is not necessarily categorized according to one’s nationality or race. Despite any differences on values, people should be entitled to ‘citizenship’ and the freedom to express their views and ideas. Regardless of values, everyone should perform their social responsibilities based on their abilities and roles in the society.

answers.a2: While I didn’t actually learn about how they connect with each other, I do remember they emphasized the significance of practicing citizenship and performing social responsibilities.

answers.a3:
Our school valued the importance of students as critical thinkers, and teachers encouraged us to express, analyze, discuss, and debate on different stances. It’s not a forceful, top-down indoctrination of certain messages or propositions.
 However, in reality, complying to the power structure and dynamics (i.e. seniority in different contexts) is way more impactful and easier for one to achieve certain goals than being critical about things. Most of the time, seniors or people on the upper levels of the hierarchy will not (easily) accept and embrace ideas contributed by the ones with a lower rank. Critical thinking is no longer considered valuable as one attempts to move up the social ladder, and will gradually be replaced by submissiveness and obsequiousness.

answers.a4:
Family: might not be a place where morally sound values would be instilled 
 Identity: something that can be deprived 
 Citizenship: something that needs to be endowed with instead of a right 
 Social responsibility: something that can be ignored when it doesn’t benefit one’s self-interest

answers.a5: I’ve become more conscious about these concepts but have not yet taken any specific actions.

answers.a6: Education should provide more opportunities to train students to be critical thinkers. However, the current circumstances have turned education into a tool to train and shape educators and institutions with indoctrinated default (political) stances. It’s no longer a suitable place for nurturing our next generation’s critical thinking and students to decide on their own stances.

answers.a7: In an environment with a preset political stance, it will be extremely difficult to establish a space for free or open thinking. The direction of education will not encourage (or even strongly oppose) independent thinking and only inculcation will remain (especially for subjects related to social studies,history, and politics, etc.)

questions.q2: (2) In school (or when you were still in school), how does (or did) your learning and/or teaching experience connect with the concepts of home, identity, citizenship, and social responsibility?

questions.q4: (4) Specifically, have social-political events since the Hong Kong 2019 protests changed your perceptions on the concepts of home, identity, citizenship, and social responsibility? If so, how? If not, why?

questions.q5: (5) (continued) Have you got more conscious and motivated to act upon these concepts? How so?

answers.a1: Home is where people feel comfortable, feel that they belong there and have the sense of belonging attached to the place. It's more psychological and posts a rather stark contrast to citizenship, which is a political term, mainly cares about the place of birth or the passports people are holding. A household address might indicate one's citizenship, but this doesn't necessarily tell you where the home is. Social responsibility, though, would be more bounded to the actual place and society where the individual is physically located. This could be a different place from where one's citizenship indicates. All these multifaceted elements and more, would shape one's identity. These concepts are often brought onto the same table but it's very complicated to dissect due to the fluidity and contextuality.

answers.a2: I think we all learnt 'Hong Kong is my home' during the kindergarten and primary school years, perhaps drew images and wrote pieces for Chinese and English assignments. In that sense, our education omitted or skipped the concept of citizenship, automatically referring home and citizenship to the same place. With that assumption in mind, we learnt basic social responsibilities like no littering or no law-breaching. We did talk about personal growth in secondary school but I don't think I had learnt much from it. The identity piece really comes through social interactions and personal reflections.

answers.a3:
It aligns pretty well because we only learn the facts: Hong Kong is your home. Yes, why not, the house and my family are in Hong Kong. 
 Identity: you were born in Hong Kong so you are a Hong Konger and you have that citizenship. and yes, I do. 
 Social responsibility: obey the law. yes, I should and I do. 
 Unfortunately, there is another interesting alignment - the flawed practice of Hong Kong's core values, such as fairness/equality, justice, and democracy. When I was in middle school, a schoolmate and I both got caught wearing sports outfits to school (which was not allowed according to school rules). I was brought to the vice principal and penalized even though I had a sound reason but the other girl would walk straight to class without any interference because she was the captain of a school team which was winning multiple competitions at that time. Funny enough, I was also part of the team, but only too new for the vice principal to recognize me at that time. Throughout my secondary school life, I kept hearing and experiencing these types of mistreatment so I was aware of prejudice, injustice, and inequality rather early compared to my peers. Consequently, except for my family, my sense of belonging is very weak in general.

answers.a4: Not exactly on these concepts but how I relate myself to these concepts and how I relate myself to Hong Kong. As I've just said, I don't have a strong sense of belonging. This allows me to keep a distance when understanding and analyzing what's actually happening. I keep myself informed because I'm familiar with the place, my family and friends are there, and I want to know the development of the situation.

answers.a5: I'd say yes for identity because all my friends who are not from Hong Kong have been curious about the situation and contexts so these conversations serve as a constant reminder that I am a Hong Konger. I have also been reaching out to several NGOs, asking if they would need any assistance in organizing events concerning protesters' mental state. It's not an act out of any of these concepts per se, but a genuine thought to help support individuals to go through the traumatic experience.

answers.a6: So far, education in Hong Kong is still extremely fact-based, asking students to recite definitions and examples and go sit for a test or exam. Societies and the world, however, is very fluid, it is ever-changing. Education should crack down those single definitions and make us aware how those labels are creating and exacerbating our current social and global issues. It is not simply about acknowledging the need for global citizenship education, identifying different issues and brainstorming potential solutions, but critically comprehending, discussing, and addressing the problems through children's lens.

answers.a7: While I think Hong Kong would just be like another city in China, its broader idea of education and its approach would be similar to whatever the global trend would be.

answers.a1: 基本上是古時五倫的概念。君臣、父子、夫婦、兄弟、朋友。君臣就是現今的國家。香港由於長期殖民地统治，有國才有家的觀念香港人基本都沒有。 It's basically the Five Cardinal Relationships in ancient times. They are those between the ruler and the subject, i.e. today's government and citizens; between the father and the son, i.e. the parents and the offspring; between siblings; and between friends. These comprise the most important relationships in society. “There’s no home without a country” (有國才有家) - basically Hong Kong people don’t have this concept since Hong Kong had been under colonial rule for so long.

answers.a2:
除了我幼時讀古文，論語，歷史外，老師的解說很重要。
 In addition to reading ancient literature, the Analects (論語), and history when I was young, the teachers’ explanation was very important.

answers.a3:
基本上是一致的。重要的一點是讀書志在明理，不是要死讀書和只聽老師和明人怎麽說。要多讀不同的書，自己消化，多思考。我基本上是以五倫的基礎上去思考，因為歷史對中國的教訓太慘痛了。
 It's basically the same. Most importantly, the aim of studying and learning is to become rational, not to simply recite and thoughtlessly listen and know what the teachers and others are saying. Read more different books, process them by yourself, and think more. My thoughts are based on the Five Cardinal Relationships, because history has taught China too painfully.

answers.a4:
2019 事件更加強我對有國才有家的觀念。
 The 2019 events have strengthened my conception towards “There’s no home without a country”.

answers.a5:
有。美國為保住地位以摧毀中國為目標，將此化為民主主義與社會主義意識形態之爭。企圖將前蘇聯東歐瓦解之歷史重演。到時中國人民又再任人魚肉。現時局勢有D似中世紀時十字軍東征，基督教誓將回教趕盡殺絕，藉口是信仰不同。 
 Yes. In order to maintain its status, the United States aims to destroy China, turning this into a dispute between democracy and socialist ideologies and attempting to repeat the history of the collapse of the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. When the time comes, Chinese people would be meat on someone’s chopping block again. The current situation is quite similar to the Crusades in the Middle Ages: christians vowed to destroy Islam on the pretext of different beliefs.

answers.a6:
書本固然重要，老師怎樣教才是重中之重。師者，所以傳道授業解惑者也。傳道第一。
 Although books/texts are important, how the teacher teaches is paramount. 
 “A teacher is one who could propagate the doctrine, impart professional knowledge and resolve doubts'' (from 'On Teachers' by Han Yu). Propagate comes first.

answers.a7:
近兩年的事件徹底摧毀了中國領導層的忍耐。我之前說過，以中共的做法，不再忍耐時便會不顧一切去做任何他們認為正確的事。不會猶豫或回頭。教育將會一面倒，直接灌輸國家觀念。 
 The Chinese leadership has completely lost their patience due to the recent events. Based on the CCP’s approach, when they no longer endure, they will do whatever they think is right without hesitation or looking back. Education will be one-sided, directly instilling the country’s concepts.

answers.a1: To me, ‘family’ and ‘home’ are the same thing. Family is very important. You have all the members: dad, mom, sons and daughters, etc., and together, these relationships make us a family and entitle us a respective identity. As for citizenship and social responsibility, it’s natural that one cooperates and does what’s good for the society as a citizen. We can also see ‘family’ or ‘household’ as a unit in the society as well.

answers.a2: I believe these concepts were indeed taught at school, perhaps some social issues as well, but I didn’t really pay attention to these things.

answers.a3: As I didn’t care too much about it, I’m not sure how those concepts had interacted with my experience outside of school. However, in terms of participation or like voting, it’s true that I used to think that my participation wouldn’t matter because it wouldn’t affect anything anyways. Before the 2019 protests, this perception was quite common among Hong Kongers and I was one of them.

answers.a4: Sure, especially through events related to elections, I’ve realized the significance of social responsibility.

answers.a5: Of course. Not only did I vote at the last election, I have also become more curious, more motivated to learn about things around me and the world. Had I known more and better, I would have had a better understanding of what's really happening in the society. I would have encouraged my kids to read and learn more about history when they were young.

answers.a6: It should help learners to deeply understand their own country. When I was young, every time I travelled with my mom to her village in the mainland, I had to carry so many things for the villagers and I did not enjoy those trips. Had I known better about the socioeconomic situation back then, at least I would be more willing and proud to make those trips. Understanding the contexts matter and it certainly shapes how we perceive and feel.

answers.a7: There needs to be a genuine understanding, instruction, and experience of our country’s history and situation.
